column4: I have a USB card reader, I use with it a 256 MB SD, I can view its contents, but I can't write files on it as user, only as root
I have a USB card reader, I use with it a 256 MB SD, I can view its contents, but I can't write files on it as user, only as root
I'm not up on USB  stuff - maybe someone else can help you
it's probably just a matter of changing the permissions on the device
have you tried setting it with the hdparm utility?
I don't know how to set it with hdparm; I currently use hdparm to tuen hdisk in regard of I/O and multicount, how to change udma mode?
I don't recall offhand, but I know it's possible with one of the switches: it's in the manual anyway (sorry that isn't meant to be a RTFM :) )
maybe open man hdparm and do a search - /dma ?
sorry  /udma
I saw in google there are many warnings about using hdparm's switches; I read about some dangerous uses of X switch
and about a man browser for X? in kde it's simple : #manpage in konqueror; why not in gnome?
hmm... yes there is some risk I believe: it hasn't broken anything here though - and if you know your hard drive's capabilities you should be OK
hmmm - it's an issue: it used to call yelp but jdub or someone was saying it needs to be fixed in gnome
I mean the man function
in gnome 2.4 ( what I'm using here on debian) , entering man:hdparm in galeon opens the gnome help browser
I don't know why I can open the normal browser in ubuntu : each dir is opened in a new window, and I can't see the tree structure on the left hand... why?
it's called "spatial" - you can chnge it in nautilus to "browser" mode
so what do I have to do? do I have to run nautilus?
but don't address all your questions to me
OK! thanks
